titlestmt.titleproper: Inventory of the George Haven Putnam papers, circa 1800-1931

publicationstmt.publisher: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

profiledesc.creation: Finding aid encoded by Ann Mulfort January 2013

did.head: Collection Summary
did.unittitle: George Haven Putnam papers

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: University of Wyoming. American Heritage Center.

bioghist.head: Biography of George Haven Putnam
bioghist.p: George Haven Putnam was the son of publisher George Palmer Putnam, founder of G.P. Putnam & Co., which had offices in New York and London. He served during the Civil War with the 176th New York Volunteers from 1862-1865, rising to the rank of major. As a prisoner of war, he spent the winter of 1864-1865 in Libby and Danville prisons. Putnam joined his father's publishing house after the Civil War and became head of G.P. Putnam's Sons in 1872, a position he held until his death in 1930. He was an organizer of the American Copyright League in 1887 and was instrumental in the development of American copyright law.

Putnam was actively involved in the English-Speaking Union, the American Rights League, the Free Trade League, and support of the League of Nations. From 1926 until his death he devoted his efforts to creating an endowed chair in American history at the University of London. Putnam wrote several books and lectured widely on subjects including his Civil War experiences, Abraham Lincoln, copyright, censorship, publishing, free trade, American-British relations and Washington Irving.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection includes correspondence with many writers, political leaders and other notables (1840-1931); texts and notes for speeches; articles and publications by Putnam; scrapbooks of personal and Putnam Co. memorabilia; and miscellaneous other materials.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: There are no access restrictions on the materials for research purposes, and the collection is open to the public.

userestrict.head: Copyright Information
userestrict.p: The researcher assumes full responsibility for observing all copyright, property, and libel laws as they apply.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: There are no known other archival collections created by George Haven Putnam at the date of processing.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The collection was received from Jessie Hale in 1972.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Finding aid encoded by Katelyn Wittenborn and Zachary Carmichael in October 2020.

Sears, and others. Also, newspaper clippings.

Washington Irving. Several pieces, including the Authors Club program for Washington Irving Evening, 1914; Memorandum of property of Washington Irving, drawn up 1857; Legal papers, 4 agreement, 57 copyrights.
Letters to G. P. Putnam from Revenue Office. 4 pieces.
Notification of election to the Athenaeum club.
Outlines for proposed books by Frederick S. Dellenbaugh, submitted G. P. Putnam's Sons. 8 pieces.
Open letter "To the publishers of the United States concerned with copyright productions, or who are, on any grounds, interested in international relations." By George Haven Putnam.
Photographs. Mrs. Beatrice Harraden, 2 pictures. 1 simulated photograph of the Knickerbocker Press. 3"x4".
Poem. "To Catherine," by Rev. Joseph Dennie Tyler.
Political leaflet, New York, with cartoon.
Poster. "Fourth of July, 1918." Extracts from Tennyson and Whittier poems concerning the relationship between England and America.
Programs. The Economic Club of Brockton; The Economic Club of Boston; Lincoln Centenary, held in 46 public schools of New York; 19th Army Corps 28th Annual meeting and dinner.
Publisher's Lunch Club. 2 copies of their constitution.
Review. "Peace and Justice Throughout the World," by George Haven Putnam, reviewed for The Churchman by Mrs. James V. Chalmers. Typed copy. 2 pages.
Subcommittee of the Senate Committee on the Indian Affairs. Itinerary.
